job_title: Registered Nurse, Emergency Room in Riverview, FL
pros: Hospital is located in Riverview Florida.
cons:
ER nursing staff is overwhelmed and overworked. St Joseph South ER management does not care about acuity of the patients in an assignment, just getting as many people seen as fsst as possible. There are no paramedics at all, and no respiratory staff assigned to the ER. Therefore almost zero nursing support. And the EMTs staffed in the ER are only utilized to clean rooms (poorly) between patients. They do not help out by performing ECGs, apply splints or any other duties a EMT could do. They only clean. 
Management does not care if you are drowning with three level one patients. In fact you will never have only two or three patients. You will always have at least four and usually five. 
This is most likely the reason the staff in the ER are majority travel nurses. 
I highly recommend not working in the ER at St Joseph South if you care about your patients safety or your nursing license.

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Dunedin, FL
pros: Depending on the location and office, could be a great experience. Benefits were as expected.
cons: The managers at several locations should not be managers. They care more about "making the customer happy" than having a healthy work environment for their staff. They do not take suggestions well, overwork you, and the pay is below average. Very obvious favoritism. Difficult to take PTO or sick days. Severe inequality in salary for the same position/office. Depending on the office, bullying and middle school level drama/gossip was a common theme. Difficult to move up in the company. They promote the "talent team" on their website so you can find an office that best suits you, but pressure you to commit after only 2 locations by threatening your job. Usually, the offices that are hiring are those with a high turnover rate due to management or doctors, so it's unlikely you'll find a good office after only 2 tries. Over the course of 2 years, I've worked at 7 offices between Tampa, Clearwater, and Dunedin, and only liked 2. My advice is to look at a different company that pays more!

pros: Great staff and some of the best co-workers. Same patients for weeks so you get to really see their progress. Learn a lot on drains, lines, vents, teach, etc. Most doctors there are nice. Patients been hospitalized for a long time so if they are covid, they'll hopefully less contagious? Criteria for admissions are stricter so less admissions/discharges. Doctor rounds like the icu so takes time from your busy schedule but you get to learn.
cons: Micromanaged. Management and staff has high turnover due to being required to do way more than they should. Basically a PCU so 5 patients too much. You are assigned to be 1 of the RRT/Code team and have your own patients too. Scheduling is a joke, only 1 person doing the schedule. Even though Kronos is the scheduling system, they go by the paper requests and it'll change without notifying you. No way to know when requests are approve. A lot of politics. Lots of travelers prior to covid too. Unsafe short staff ina all disciplines. Get mistreated by a lot of the patient's family and no recognition for going beyond. Reports to managers does nothing, you are "complaining". No staff wants to come to unit to help cause they know how exhausting it. Is. 99% total max assist patients. job_title: Chaplain Resident in Safety Harbor, FL
pros: The best point of working with BayCare is the overwhelming positive work environment. The compassion for the patients is indescribable and the mutual encouragement shared between the various members of the medical staff is exceptional. It is not unusual to find people who have worked here for 25 and 30+ years.
cons: I seriously can not think of a down side to working here. This is as best as I can do: the traffic light has extended red signals at the entrance of the hospital.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Pinellas Park, FL
pros: BayCare is a great organization overall.  The mission to improve the health of the community is a strong part of the culture.  There are good advancement opportunities for individuals with skillsets that allow them to move across the organization. Compensation is pretty competitive.
cons: Leadership, particularly IS, is very political and unrealistic about what it takes to deliver results on initiatives.  There is a lot of talk and very little walk.  The end result is understaffed projects and inefficient workarounds.  Leadership is stuck in the past and needs to look outside the healthcare industry for inspiration.  They seem to be about 10 years behind other industries.  There is nothing special about the benefits, especially healthcare coverage.  There is no casual Friday or working from home.

pros: There are many new hospitals opening in the area that require all nurses to have Bachelor degrees and up.  So you don't have to just pick one or two hospitals anymore.
cons:
Baycare is a not for profit that cares about profit. I work in surgery and can tell you that management does not care about patients, they care about money. 
I seen so many good nurses leave because of these idiots. 
The management will find ways to get rid of you if you know what you are doing because you become a threat to their job. Most do not have more than an associates degree, yet still they supervise people with Bachelors and Masters degree as if they know what they are doing.
If you work here, stay quiet, do your time, get a bachelors and get out fast.  Other hospitals in the area will treat you with more respect and better working conditions.  Avoid baycare.  There is a reason they are always trying to recruit new people, they keep losing staff.  Do not sign a 3 year contract for work, you will be stuck and miserable like them.

job_title: Medical Laboratory Assistant in Clearwater, FL
pros: Excellent resources for health insurance and employee assistance. Higher management seems to praise employees. An amazing amount of health care resides within. Extremely good intentions for growth. There are an amazing amount of discounts for employees at MANY different businesses and apartment complexes due to the name.
cons: No situational exceptions seem to exist for this company. If a mistake is made while handling more than what's required, there is no remorse from Human Resources or management. I helped facilitate many things for special purposes but I was treated like a common slattern. The only reward I got for doing things was to keep my job even after abuse from a previous supervisor. I was told this specifically while getting a review that was substandard after assisting with changes to the company and giving up personal time. The whole process for ambulatory was designed for employee turnaround. If you're paid too much, you will be fired.

review_title: Avoid Hampton Lakes Out Patient Center, Safety Harbor
pros: Good pay and benefits. I loved the other technologist.
cons: This is the only location with an Open Mri within the Baycare outpatient system. You will be expected to produce the same amount of patient volume as compared to many other closed magnets throughout the community.  You will work alone and be required to obtain previous labs, studies, and communicate with the Dr's offices and run I-stats when needed. If there is an angry patient in the waiting room you are asked to keep the patient informed and at ease.  The front desk and Radiologist can not leave until you are finished scanning the last patient..of course, you are always behind schedule and they stand behind your back asking why you are behind schedule..... The best part is when you sit down with your manager each month and discuss your ranking v/s all other Mri facilities.. Got to love those patient surveys :). You better be the happiest most fabulous tech on the  list- or the manager gets a little bent out of shape.  That's when the fun begins.. The facility is open 7 days a week.......Beware

pros: Work from home option open to some, good health benefits, decent PTO. The brand attracts good talent and you will likely enjoy your coworkers. Did not lay off positions as a result of the pandemic and still gave employees cost of living raises. Many women in leadership positions.
cons: No consistent leadership. Dismal minority representation in leadership and very hard to grow within the organization but especially as a minority. Senior leadership says they value diversity and their employees but then require them to return to the office when they project the pandemic to be highest and have cut leadership positions in a way that disproportionately affects minorities. As a result of the pandemic many departments are severely understaffed. Do not expect work life balance.

pros: They pay you and mess it up from time to time, but at least they pay you.
cons: You are considered the lowest of the company. You're just a transporter. You are pushed to get 3 patients an hour and whenever you voice opinions or concerns to management, you are never heard. I hate my job at BayCare, the only reason I'm still working there is because I need to make ends meet. They write you up for anything and everything, work you to the bone, degrade your work and efforts, and will literally write you up to keep you from transferring to a different department.

review_title: Get experience and get out of corporate office
pros: You can work 4 day work week.  Okay benefits. New office building but treated like your in jail. A few nice coworkers.
cons: The Managed Care Dept hires people that aren't qualified for the job.  They pick and choose who they want for growth behind closed doors. They post a job for an hour and let only the person they choose get the chance to apply.  The director pretends to care but gossips a lot behind employees backs. The VP struggles to even say hello to her employees because they are beneath her.  The office environment is set up like a prison. Stand up to talk to a coworker and your stared at by management.  The thought of letting people work from home is not even allowed to be brought up because management can't imagine not having control over people and treating them like adults.

pros: St. Anthony's was a wonderful place to work. Great senior admin and support. Genuinely concerned about providing quality care. The president of St. A is the best in the system.
cons: No chance for advancement across the system. BayCare preaches that they like to promote from within, but no one gets a serious interview unless it is for your the hospital that you work for. Other hospitals in system do not want to work together, but rather see everything as a competition and middle leadership collaboratives across the system are ineffectual and stuck in the past. Pay is horrible compared to other systems in the area. Everyone in management is titled one position under what they really do so they can pay less.

job_title: Mental Health Technician in New Port Richey, FL
pros: Promotions are great if you bust your butt and do what management preens you to do.  Time off policies were great, but they weren't set by those I was in direct contact with.  Most of the staff I was with were friendly with each other.
cons: Long hours, extra time added to shifts.  Not a lot of management help in senior positions, other staff micromanages new people.  There's room for personal growth if you're part of the clique.  Staff don't always treat clients very well, snide remarks after the person has walked away.  Have personally seen nurses and other ER staff badmouth patients in the open hallways infront of other patients and family.  Not a place I would want to be!

review_title: Pays well, but not much opportunity for advancement.
pros: The pay is competitive, and the benefits are good.  They offer great services to the community, and the team members usually work well together.  There does some to be a degree of high school social behavior, which I believe is unprofessional in any job, but especially in health care.
cons: It is difficult to get promoted, even with advanced education.  Even if you take on extra projects to better the company, senior management will take the credit for your ideas and cut you out of the project. Policies and procedures change often, so when you forget, or make a mistake (because you just got used to the "old" way), you get called in to the office for a reprimand.  Management also makes it a point to remind you that you are replaceable, which negatively impacts morale.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Land O' Lakes, FL
pros: Benefits are okay.  Paid time off accrues well the longer that you are with the company.  Continued education offered through the company at no cost to employee.  401k match program is decent.
cons: To few workers for all of the positions.  Management always wanting to cut staff to a bare minimum with complete disregard of the employees or the patients that it is caring for at the time.  Moral is at an all time low due to the fat that everyone is always on edge of keeping their position.  High employee turn over due to working conditions and complete lack of respect given to the employees by management team.

pros: Lots of training! They really emphasize  education and pay for it. My managers were very competent and professional.
cons: I worked on a very busy floor, and sometimes none of my patients are able to be independent even with basic needs. Almost every shift I have a 'primary' patient that I do all the vital signs, accuchecks if needed, bathe, change bed linens, and chart I&O, everything a tech would usually do for the patient/RN. This is ok if the shift is going fine and the patient is somewhat independent. But occasionally the patient load is really heavy and its that extra little bit that can cause an otherwise busy day to go spiraling out of control.

pros: Pay is above what other healthcare companies pay in the area depending on the job title and where you work within the system.
cons: Insurance is horrible.  Once someone gets into management they are untouchable and golden.  Many managers play favorites.  Policy and procedures are only there to protect the company they will never help the employee.  It will only be a waste of time to try to do anything against management as team resources will only rule in favor of the manager.  It's not about how hard you work they like "yes" people and anyone who will brown nose their way to the top.  If you're a puppet then you'll do well in this company.

pros: Good benefits.  Definitely nice work environment.  Great communities.
cons:
I found management to be inconsistent.  Many played favorites.  One unit I was at, if the manager didn't personally like you, but could find nothing to write you up on, they would make that persons life miserable until they left.
I also found management to be deaf when it came to bullying.  I witnessed so many good people leave when management would not help.  Especially when the bully was a lower level manager.

job_title: Preoperative Systems Analyst in Clearwater, FL
pros: Competitive salary, promote from within, competent leadership, decent benefits, many insider perks that come with the job (payroll deduct, HERO club, on-site sales, etc.)
cons: My biggest complaint is the withholding of information from those who are in positions that are scarce. It seems that some elite positions are nearly impossible to get information from. They guard their processes and procedures and insist they perform the inquiry and get back to you but yet they don't have enough time to return the information to you in a timely manner. Furthermore, Ive noticed some of these people safeguard those who might be higher up in the chain than they are. When prompted for a point of contact, they insist that they relay communications. Its widespread and not limited to one person. Very counter-productive.

review_title: Not Good but the only option almost
pros: There are a lot of kind, skilled, amazing people who work here. Unfortunately, management crushes them and either keeps people quiet through fear of losing their job (and since it is the main employer of the entire are of that part of FL, that is a huge deal). or has people turning against each other
cons: Management issues, where to begin? Discrimination against disabilities (in a hospital that works with said disabilities!). Conflict of interest between physicians the employees must see through the health insurance, and the health care system that one works in - leading to some serious issues. The raises are not even enough to make up for inflation. No upward movement. All about who you know, not very ethical.

review_title: Lack of professionalism; Management ineffective managing team members' bad behaviors
pros:
Health benefits are excellent as long as you stay within the BayCare network
Facility is very nice work environment
cons:
Sophomoric behavior amongst team members – highly competitive, not sharing info required to do job, talking behind each other’s backs, bullying, and back-stabbing.  
Supervisor unable to manage team and frequently choose sides; shared comments about whichever team member was on her list at that time with others in the bullpen.  
The BayCare values of trust, respect and dignity were not practiced by the supervisor or the members of this team.  Upper management did nothing to address the dysfunctional and counterproductive behaviors.
Unable to work from home

pros: I had no problems with the benefits almost everything was covered. My Health Saving plans always rolled over and you can continue to use the funds each year.
cons: have never worked in such a terrible environment. I would have to come to work and focus on taking over 100 calls a day.  There is a ton of gossip and hear-say. I had two coordinators and supervisor who had no interest in helping patients or team -members.  My  felt my supervisor had no people skills to  handle the department duties. There is no room for advancement you can do your best and expect to be stuck there.  My supervisor didn't even have a degree to be a supervisor.  Every year your bonuses get smaller and you are lucky if you get .50 cent raise for the year.  They will let you know your unable to go to break if the call volume is over 5. This is the worse company I have ever worked for run as far as you can.

review_title: Poor Patient Care and What an awful Culture  - dont do what you say but expect everyone else to do!
pros: The health system is in Tampa Bay - what a beautiful area
cons: The  stated values are no where in action.  The nursing care is simply awful at Morton Plant Meese - with no accountability for care delivered to patients and families.  In all my years as a nurse I have never seen anything like it.  In event of a serious iillness my family is going elsewhere.   The Senior Nursing Leadership is so self asborbed and lack knowledge of the real world.   Blame Blame Blame is the way of life.   I came from a health system that had a very advanced evidenced based shared goverance approach and it was light years of this insitution.  Infections and other problems are the way of life.

pros: Nice offices and nice equipment to work with.  About half of the IT Staff seem to have a fair amount of knowledge.  Nice demographic ratio of employees.  Very pleasant city.
cons: Management in IT is totally clueless.  Some of the programmers that really knew their stuff, and cared about what the physicians and nurses needed to do their jobs, and produced some amazing results wind up losing their jobs by getting written up for non-programming things.  One written up after working many long hours, then had to leave early one day for emergency and got axed.  Major tension throughout the whole IT department.  Directors in IT area, totally incompetent, and will throw any of their people under the bus.  If you work in IT, and need a job, there are hundreds of better places to land.

review_title: My experience has been rewarding and educational
job_title: Registered Nurse in Palm Harbor, FL
pros: There is room for growth within the company and you get a sense of satisfaction on a personal level when helping people . You also get to work with a good team and they make sure their staff is properly trained.
cons: Our people in the community are chronically sick due to the overuse of medications and misdiagnosis. Therefore, it is extremely hard on the healthcare professionals caring for these people and it becomes hard on the body, mind, and soul. 12 hour shifts are not healthy for the staff or the patients; mistakes can be made due to this.

review_title: Experience will depend on department and manager
job_title: Social Service Specialist in Tampa, FL
pros: Many locations, able to transfer to another department or location within 6 months of employment, good overall benefits, many opportunities for advancement for direct patient care staff.
cons: In many cases, although not part of the company's values, your career growth and future will depend on your direct manager and their specific department and career goals for themselves.  One person has the power to either make or break you, loyalty and experience will not always get you where you want to go.  This is still a "good-ol-boy" type environment in some departments.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Lutz, FL
pros: Our nursing managers really cares about the staff. I am a tech in a 30 bed unit and when i first started, there would be 3 techs on the floor so we would each get ten patients. Recently she hired a lot of staff so now there will be four techs on the floor which really makes a huge difference! So now 2 techs will have 7 patients and the other 2 will have 8 patients which tremendously improve the quality of patient care. Another reason why Baycare is one the best hospitals is because they really emphasize on quality care which is was makes it one of the best hospitals in the Tampa Bay area.
cons: Nothing bad to say about this hospital

pros: Good Benefits, good co workers!
cons: Terrible Management, ZERO policies, TONS of inconsistencies,  to many clicks with upper management. Management is too nit picky and unappreciative of the hard work of their employees. The RIGHT HAND DOES NOT TALK TO THE LEFT HAND. ZERO room to move up in the company. ZERO communication and zero acknowledgement for a job well done, if you do get an acknowledgment its followed by what more you could do. counterproductive just like all the rules they try to implement.

job_title: Emergency Department RN in Tampa, FL
pros: The pay is competitive for the area, but still low based on the US average
cons: Preceptors are not properly trained and/or experienced. There are many that only have 1 year of nursing experience period. I’ve never experienced “nurse bullying” like I did at St. Joseph’s. They will chew you up, spit you out and then ostracized you! This was an horrible experience. Patient care is second to patient satisfaction. As long as the patient “thinks you are nice and know what you’re doing,”  you don’t really have to know what you’re doing. I would never take my family there. Very miserable environment. Staff are not happy. Most are waiting on contracts to end so that they can leave.

review_title: Clinical ladder to success in healthcare field
job_title: Registered Nurse in Clearwater Beach, FL
pros: Offers a place for a graduate nurse to learn under the care of many mentors.   Provides a safe environment in which continuous quality improvement is encouraged. Many educational opportunities both in-house and financial compensation for out-of-house.
cons: Healthcare workers with high standards of care must learn to navigate the current of  workers with lower standards of care, at times.  There can be territorial defensive personality types in critical care, high stress environments.

pros: The pay and staff are amazing. I don't mind floating to various units because everyone is pleasant to work with.
cons: The management quality has went down. There's no communication. I work in the Mobil Pool Unit and no one ever returns my call.  I asked via email what part time contracts were available (so I can see my options). Instead I was sent via email a full time contract that said sign and return.  When I sent an email requesting a call back; its a week later and I am still waiting...

job_title: Customer Service Specialist in Clearwater, FL
pros:
Good pay . Benefits and work
Perks.
cons: Micromanagement . A lot of favoritism. And managers like to entertain office gossip and rumors . We really have to watch who we’re around and what we do what we say . Because you never know who may be around to use it against you .

review_title: Only as good as the manager
pros: They have decent starting salary and benefits.
cons: Management. They chose not to give at least 3% increase and have the attitude you are lucky to have a job. They do not care about the employee. They can and do blackball you from switching hospitals. HR will not even speak to you without the managers input. If you ask to be transferred the manager can and usually does, tell HR it is not a good idea.

job_title: Senior Systems Analyst in Clearwater, FL
pros: Challenging, Friendly, Long Term, Reliable, and well paid Plenty of work to do. Many different places to work.
cons: Old school processes still in place. Many are changing but plenty still there. Hard to convince some people who work here that improving the way they do their job can be a good thing.

review_title: Great place to get healthcare IT experience, not a lot of opportunity to move up.
job_title: Clinical Applications Analyst in Clearwater, FL
pros: Access to cutting edge technology, lots of opportunities to train and learn different systems.  The organization as a whole works hard to treat employees with dignity and respect.
cons: Not much opportunity to move upward, although the state that they "promote from within", I haven't seen it.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: Great benefits, lots of resources, lots of training, a lot of employee perks (i.e. the biggest loser weight loss challenges and smoking cessation classes), better staff ratios than other for-profit hospitals, a large hospital system that is easy to transfer from one location to another, large holiday party
cons: While working there, staffing ratios did go up and they stopped being as generous with overtime.  It wasn't always easy to take a lunch break, but it was required by management, so if you took care of your patients and went without your break you could get in trouble.

review_title: I have been able to grow both personally and professionally in my 26 years of employment.
pros: Designated Magnet status makes Morton Plant Hospital a wonderful place to grow and learn as a nurse. You are encouraged to learn and expand your knowledge with much support from management and community resources.
cons: One of the downsides of working at Morton Plant is that because it is so large, nurses are often are not aware of who their senior management team is and are afraid to contact them with concerns.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: Pay is decent compared to most hospital networks in the area.  Staffing is always a shortage and expected to have a heavy nurse to patient caseload.
cons: Environment is toxic and sort of has that "who you know" atmosphere with respect to getting promotional opportunities.  A bit of the old mentality of lateral nurse violence and eating their young.

pros:
- You will never be bored! Work was challenging, and sometimes the hours long. 
- Great coworkers! I have a lot of respect for those I worked with
- Good benefits: the regular stuff plus 401K (fully vested after 5 years); tuition reimbursement; vacation, sick and holidays rolled into one bucket of PTO
- Room to grow in many cases: they are always building facilities and buying older ones to include in the network
cons: - In MY case, there was not room to grow. To move up, I needed to move on

review_title: The management team at many sites are like a high school click.
job_title: X Ray Tech in Largo, FL
pros: Generally the co workers are a great group to work with.
cons: The employees doing the day to day jobs generally seem to care about what they are doing.  Senior management cares about the numbers only.  They do not have a clue about what is going on at many of the sites.  Managers and directors come and go as they please.  They do not listen to the employees about anything.  They say they listen but they do not.  You can forget about ever moving up in the organization unless you know someone.  People that are extremely qualified are just passed over.  They only follow the policies when it suits them.

review_title: Great experience in the geriatric field, then the float team until i was wrongfully terminated
pros: Love the patients. Great opportunities available in offices other that the PCP office I worked for. Awesome training by Dunedin PC. New experiences on the float team.
cons: No correctional action taken for unlawful behavior ie: forging doctors signatures on controlled substance prescriptions, stealing medication samples meant for patients, never at work per schedule, playing games and facebooking during work hours, dodging needy patients from seeing a doctor, and sleeping while in team leader meetings.

review_title: Registered Nurse - Med Surg Tele floor
job_title: Registered Nurse, CNII in Tampa, FL
pros: Good team to work with, career advancement, mentorship, tuition reimbursement, team member skills workshops, free access to CE Direct and the CEU sites, self scheduling, my specific managers really work with you if you have something personal come up, good support
cons: Favoritism, reprimand whole group instead of finding the individual, some managers do not honor self scheduling, CNIII 9with manager ok) can work no weekends while rest of staff have to work extra to balance, awards based on popular vote instead of hard work

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Clearwater, FL
pros: Wonderful, dedicated fellow employees who truly work as a team and make each day more bearable.
cons:
Extremely low pay for the responsibilities that are place on you, staff to patient ratio is ridiculous to the point of being hazardous, and the types of patients admitted aren't always safe to be around.

A lot of drug addicts and Baker Act "patients" you deal with on a daily basis that you aren't trained to handle.

review_title: Watch out for Baycare Behavioral Health
job_title: Therapist in New Port Richey, FL
pros: Good health care and other benefits.
cons:
Overall I was extremely disappointed with my experience. My immediate supervisor had no clinical skills. If she doesn't like you, game over. If something goes wrong be sure that the supervisor will blame you and not take responsibility for anything and make false reports to upper management. 

I was very disappointed with Baycare they promote good values that seem great, but in the behavioral health offices programs in Pasco County they don't care about your actual work performance its rather if you can succeed making it with poor supervision. You can be fired within the first 6 months of your orientation period of working there basically without cause and you won't have a second to defend yourself.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Fruitland Park, FL
pros: Caring, compassionate coworkers who try to support each other.
cons: Organization cut RN home health wages by a minimum of 35% - the further you drive, the less you make. For a company of this size, the technology available to do this job is 1990's era, making it even harder to be productive.  Can't trust your paycheck to be accurate. You have to monitor and analyze your visits and mileage. Big Headache - not worth it.

pros: The biggest pro is the mid-level employees (not management). There are some truly great people there - some of the best I’ve worked with. The corporate office is large and very clean. The company is growing so jobs are very secure. Tenure is a big thing there - employees come and they stay for a long time.
cons: BayCare corporate is a great place to work if you’re an older person, or if you’re looking for an easy job that doesn’t require much of you.  It’s like going backwards in time to corporate America 40-50 years ago. You’ll see signs on lace doilies next to a vase of fake flowers that say “shhh, be quiet” and talking or laughing in your cubicle is frowned upon. Extremely formal dress code. Women wear pantyhose to work. There are no casual Fridays except for rare fundraisers and you have to pay to wear jeans for the fundraiser. No work from home option. Really behind the times in all aspects. I remember sitting in a meeting and forecasting was introduced as a novel concept. They do things the same way they always have and don’t like change or new ideas. Way too many employees, each with a tiny realm of responsibility that they take very seriously, but it’s not challenging or rewarding. Employees are underutilized. It’s just monotonous work. I didn’t learn anything or grow in my career there.  Departments are very siloed. Of all the managers, VPs, and Directors I met there, only a handful were qualified to be in the roles they were, and they should have been higher level than they were at but most likely would never be promoted. The company just needs to enter this century. Employees need to be allowed to have voices and opportunities to grow the company and push it forward, as well as develop themselves professionally. The BayCare health insurance is limited to their own BayCare network and it was AWFUL. Worst doctors ever. Prepare to lose every good doctor you’ve used because they won’t be in the BayCare network. Coverage is terrible also. You’ll pay a ton in uncovered medical expenses. It was the worst insurance I’ve ever had. Another con is the lack of young people there. Most employees are in their 50’s and above. No maternity leave - you have to use your PTO. But they’ll tell you they have paid maternity leave because they consider your PTO paid leave (2 weeks per year). For a medical corporation as large as BayCare, to offer no paid maternity leave is a slap in the face.

pros: For the most part co workers do care about Baycare's mission.
cons: Advancement decisions are made on personal impressions and not on true skills.   Employees who work twice as hard as others are overlooked because are not part of the group.  Company hires from outside instead of giving current employees the opportunity to grow and learn new skills.  Management at all levels does not know what is going on in the departments.

pros: Regular schedules, decent benefits and the chance to work with some wonderful nurses, doctors, and other clinical and non clinical staff.
cons: Uneducated supervisors, with little to no HR training.  Inconsistent discipline, if you are a favorite employee, you are immune to disciplinary actions, if not, you will be "written up" for every infraction.  Supervisors have been known to threaten to throw food in employees faces, throw clipboards at subordinates, humiliate employees by telling everyone in the office any transgression the employee might have committed, etc.  HR is of no help because the hospitals are so spread out, they don't know what goes on and after awhile, you just feel so defeated, that it is not worth continuing to work there.  Very high turnover rate for Security and certain employees walk around on pins and needles, while others could care less, and it's obvious.  No chance of upward mobility and I have never seen anyone within Security be able to transfer to another department, no matter how miserable they may be.  I have seen employees walk off the job, not incentive, but twice, but received absolutely no discipline, but if you are late, or using your phone, you will be chastised and threatened with termination.  They don't care how you treat the patients, anger management, etc.  because they are more concerned with important things like phone usage, and these important, earth shattering issues.  No one is trained on report writing, so some of us had to write them for everyone.  Just a bad work experience, and one I was grateful to leave.

review_title: Great place to work. Happy to be a team member
job_title: Physical Therapist in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: Baycare is a company that is most of the time trying to do the right thing for the patient. It is not a compay that is driven by a shareholder's interest, unlike many other Healthcare Corporations of America.
cons: The health insurance is not the best available. One of the downsides is that Baycare is a catholic based organization and their healthcare policies are still driven by that foundation

job_title: Systems Marketing Manager in Clearwater, FL
pros: Stable company, friendly people, professional environment. Excellent training programs within the organization.
cons: Executives are micro managers, refuse to give the opportunity to their employees to shine.  The marketing function lacks sound leadership skills from Directors and VP .Always putting out fires instead of providing a vision that can be supported to grow the business.

review_title: Poor structure and lack of management
pros: Great pay and benefits and overall great company to work for.
cons: Lack of structure, poor communication and poor management.  Techs get bullied to the point of crying and management just shrugs it off.  Very upsetting and unprofessional environment.  High employee turnover due to this.  This should never be an issue at a large company such as Baycare.  If an employee is bullied, HR should be involved immediately!!  The manager and director should NEVER shrug this off because they're too busy to deal with it.

pros: Financially stable, great benefits, focus on positive attitudes. They like to start meetings with what they call Quality. Quality can be anything positive you want to celebrate such as recognizing a coworker for a job well done or wishing someone happy birthday.
cons: Projects are rushed through without the proper attention to detail. Testing sessions will be scheduled and held without regard to whether or not what is being tested has been configured. Too many meetings with large groups. People are frequently scheduled for multiple meetings at the same time. How can you be in more than one place at once?

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Tampa, FL
pros: It was an easy job taking calls. That was the only pro
cons: The downsides of this job is it is on the bottom of the totem pole, down there with EVS(environmental services). Management is terrible in this department. If you messed up, you were threatened with being fired. You can not go to HR.  Pay is not that good. There are no set schedules. This is pretty much an on-call job. If you are set for 40 hours a week, you wont know until week of what your schedule is. There is so much office politics going on, it is insane. I would highly recommend not to take this job. There are many openings but please do not apply.

review_title: It was not a good experience working for this company.
job_title: Home Health RN in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: The company has decent benefits package and educational opportunities. It is a large corporation with numerous hospitals and opportunities for advancement if you have the right certifications/qualifications.
cons: There's a lot of documentation, esp. on the Medicare admissions, so I ended up working a lot on my own time at home to get it completed. There is a large turnover rate with the Home Health Nurses, which can be taken as an indication of the workload.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Safety Harbor, FL
pros: I liked the atmosphere, my manager was friendly and fair. All of my co-workers were hard working, a lot of team work.We got to make our own schedule and decided at what time we would take our breaks.There was a lot of autonomy.
cons: The health insurance was not that great, kind of expensive. Long hours 7-7. There was a lot of extra education you have to do complete each year.

job_title: Sterile Processing Tech in Tampa, FL

review_title: Enjoyed my job and going to work everyday
job_title: Patient Transporter in Safety Harbor, FL
pros: Enjoyed constant patient and team member interaction as well as assisting and helping all patients and team members whenever possible. PTO accrued quickly and was a great benefit, as well as health benefits through Baycare. Excellent teamwork and communication between transporters and transport coordinators, and Transport Department Supervisor.
cons: Periodic lack of respect by certain team members toward patient transporters. Low pay for transporters for the responsibilities expected , but opportunity for overtime.

job_title: Social Services Specialist in Tampa, FL
pros: PTO system is great, you can accrue up to 480 hours and cash in up to 100 hours a year at 100%. Supervisor and manager have an open door policy.
cons: Pay is slightly below the norm. Nurse Case Managers now do 90% of the same work as SW, but their starting pay is $20,000 more. Relationship between physicians and RN's/SW is abysmal, limited support from management when a dispute occurs.

pros: 401K plan is the only Pro I can think of and some team members that care, but are not there long enough to inflict change
cons: Horrible work load, lack of training, set up for failure, not enough hands to handle the work and terrible turnover, so got to figure out things in sinker swim mentality and no support from your team members since everyone is overworked and stressed.  Quality people leave quickly within a year and chances of transferring are slim. It was an amazing experience of how NOT to run a company

review_title: Much Better than Previous Job In Dante's 7th Circle
job_title: Clinical Nurse II in Tampa, FL
pros:
I am being paid substantially more than I was at (ahem) another, comparable, hospital in Tampa. I like the administration better; it has a simpler hierarchy and the administrators seem more inclined to accept staff input into how the hospital should be run. 

By itself, my colleagues are excellent hard workers and there is a strong team mind-set most of the time. The hospital holds staff to an appropriate standard of practice, and patient safety is made a priority. 

The morals and ethics that this institution upholds, such as it's pro-life stance and other traditionally Christian and/or Catholic views, are two of its strongest draws for me. 

The benefits package is substantial and includes 3 options each for dental insurance and vision insurance, as well as two options for health insurance.
cons: Physicians and even some MLPs are allowed to behave like power-hungry imbeciles. Burnt-out providers who don't want to put their own orders in are also allowed to bark at staff who are simply upholding standards of practice or policy and/or are concerned about patient safety and care. Providers are permitted to dump their tasks on RNs, which RNs then do for the benefit of the patient. They are allowed to take advantage of the strong sense of advocacy and urgency that the RNs have for the care of their patients. I even believe, in some cases, that MDs put their orders in incorrectly in the hopes that RNs will eventually just put in all the orders for them automatically so that it gets done right. I don't know what else to think at this point. If I could fix one thing with BayCare, this is it: providers need to be interacted with and to interact with colleagues in a team atmosphere, not as captains of an extremely unsound healthcare 'ship'. We are all part of a team, including the patient.

pros: Live their values-Trust, Dignity, Respect, Excellence, Responsibility.  Financially stable and provides top-notch service to community.   Leadership team cares about team members and Tommy Inzina our CEO has been great for growth and innovation.  Love this company!
cons: Fast paced and very high expectations.  Be prepared to work, we want to provide the best care to our patients and customers so we expect the best from our team memebers.

review_title: What ever happened to Co-worker kindness
pros: Sore feet to remind you that sitting down can be nice, conflict to remind you that being with family isn't so bad after all, and mandatory Hurricane emergency service on duty to remind you that your family is important to only you and that their safety doesn't mean anything to your employer.
cons: 12 hour shifts, no such thing as getting a 15 minute break much less a bathroom break. Supervisors talk to you like you are stupid and that your opinion is better kept to yourself, even when your opinion follows company policy and theirs is skating under the radar. You are treated like you are expendable and that there is a line of illegal immigrants just waiting to take your job, therefor they can treat you whatever way they wish. Most of all the back biting and nasty co-worker relations make an acoustic work environment. review_title: My experience with BayCare's Marketing Dept.
pros: I worked along side some dedicated, intelligent people.
cons: I have never witnessed anything like the marketing department at BayCare. Like the other reviewer who works in the marketing department, I experienced ridiculous micro-management. Though they go to great lengths to hire educated, experienced professionals, they strip everyone of decision-making power and basically make them into admins. Using your brain is frowned upon; speaking your mind can get you terminated. After a short time, team members either quit (and I saw MANY go) or they adapt to the toxic environment by squashing their feelings and "drinking the koolaid." The marketing executive team are not just poor leaders, they are extremely insecure and will throw you under the bus with a smile. Before BayCare, I was an exemplary and happy employee, and I have once again regained that with my exit. But, while I was there, I was entirely miserable. I just could not extinguish the thought that my brain and opinions were, in fact, valuable. I think of my time spent in BayCare's marketing department like a prison sentence- time where my life stopped; I learned nothing; I saw the worst in people and I prayed for freedom. Fortunately, I made it out unscathed and am back to a normal work environment where I'm treated with respect and valued for my skills.

Other hospitals in the area will treat you like a real nurse with more respect and better working conditions. Avoid baycare. There is a reason they are always trying to recruit new people, they keep losing staff. Do not sign a 3 year contract for work, you will be stuck and miserable like them.  After all, if a place is somewhat decent, you don't have to force people to stay. These are facts that are easily confirmed.

pros: Staff is mostly nice. Good skill level and make the best with lousy management.
cons:
I am a Registered Nurse, certified in the operating room (CNOR). I worked in the main operating room with mostly good staff.  The management however, is terrible and makes the work atmosphere dismal with low morale. Very high employee turnovers with factory like conditions and wages that are not guaranteed. They send you home early without pay daily. They rush and create unsafe working environments continuously. This not for profit cares about its record profit. Profit that will make you question the competency of the surgical and hospital administrations.   

The majority of scrubs worn in surgery are not laundered by the hospital. Industrial laundries reach temperatures that kill many germs found in blood, feces, and bodily fluids. That's how most hospital linen is cleaned. Instead, more profit is made by letting employees take their hospital attire scrubs home to clean in the family wash that does not reach required temperatures. Kindly ask any hospital employee on the front line of patient care, how their hospital cloths are washed and why? How often are they washed? Is it a machine? By hand? At all? Is the infection you and your loved one maybe fighting a result of this?  

"Immediate use" sterilization (formerly "flashing") is used daily in their OR as a way of processing surgical equipment. This is recommended to be used in emergencies only by most organizations. Several steps of the decontamination and dry cycles of processing surgical equipment are removed by immediate use to ensure quick turnovers of cases without having to purchase more equipment. Imagine the equipment being used on a loved one that was inside another patient less than 60 minutes prior not going through the normal routine of decontamination, assembly, sterilization and cooling. This is not good. You can see if this has happened to you or a loved one by looking at the surgical report prepared by the operating room RN. Immediate use & infection have direct correlation to one another.  Ask if a certified infection control practitioner is on hand to witness this stuff. 
Would not recommend this place for employment in surgical services or surgery. If you do, at least prepare for leaving it in a few months as a precaution. 
Please beware.  If there was ever a place needed to demonstrate why Nurses unions are required, this is the place! All the best to you in health.
